            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/curious-serpens-falsefont-backdoor/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-133071-_zdjjbbl29xlf"></a><strong>Executive Summary</strong></h2>
<p>This article reviews the recently discovered FalseFont backdoor, which was used by a suspected Iranian-affiliated threat actor that Unit 42 tracks as Curious Serpens. Curious Serpens (aka Peach Sandstorm) is a known espionage group that has previously targeted the aerospace and energy sectors. FalseFont is the latest tool in Curious Serpens’ arsenal. The examples we analyzed show how the threat actors mimic legitimate human resources software, using a fake job recruitment process to trick victims into installing the backdoor.</p>
<p>Our in-depth technical analysis will help security professionals better understand FalseFont and more effectively defend against this threat. This article focuses on analysis of the newly discovered FalseFont backdoor and its capabilities. Lastly, we’ll discuss ways to detect and prevent this targeted backdoor.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats mentioned in this article in the following ways:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> with the <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-threat-prevention/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Threat Prevention</a> security subscription can help block the malware C2 traffic</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DNS Security</a> categorize known C2 domains and IPs as malicious.</li>
<li>Organizations can engage the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response</a> team for specific assistance with this threat and others</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/datasheets/prisma-cloud-compute-edition-aag" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Prisma Cloud Compute</a> combined with the <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> platform help detect and prevent the threats mentioned in this article</li>
<li>The <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/datasheets/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> machine learning-models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of this new malware.</li>
</ul>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/iran/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Iran</strong></a>, <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/backdoor/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Backdoors</strong></a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Curious Serpens  APT Group AKAs</b></td>
<td>Peach Sandstorm, APT33, Elfin, HOLMIUM, MAGNALIUM, REFINED KITTEN</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><strong>Curious Serpens and FalseFont Background</strong></h2>
<p>The threat actor we track as Curious Serpens is also known by other names, such as <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2023/09/14/peach-sandstorm-password-spray-campaigns-enable-intelligence-collection-at-high-value-targets/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Peach Sandstorm</a>, <a href="https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/apt33-insights-into-iranian-cyber-espionage" target="_blank" rel="noopener">APT33</a>, <a href="https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/elfin-apt33-espionage" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Elfin</a>, <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2020/06/18/inside-microsoft-threat-protection-mapping-attack-chains-from-cloud-to-endpoint/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">HOLMIUM</a>, <a href="https://www.dragos.com/threat/magnallium/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">MAGNALIUM</a> or <a href="https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/who-is-refined-kitten/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">REFINED KITTEN</a>. According to these reports, Curious Serpens has been active since at least 2013. This threat actor is associated with espionage and has <a href="https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/apt33-insights-into-iranian-cyber-espionage" target="_blank" rel="noopener">targeted</a> organizations in the Middle East, the United States and Europe.</p>
<p>In December 2023, Microsoft Threat Intelligence noted that <a href="https://twitter.com/MsftSecIntel/status/1737895717870440609" target="_blank" rel="noopener">this threat actor began using a new backdoor</a> and identified the backdoor as FalseFont. By the end of January 2024, we saw the first public <a href="https://www.nextron-systems.com/2024/01/29/analysis-of-falsefont-backdoor-used-by-peach-sandstorm-threat-actor/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">analysis of FalseFont</a>. Here, we add to the analysis of FalseFont by sharing our observations, as well as additional information on the traffic and processes that we have detected and prevented.</p>
<p>The FalseFont backdoor is written in ASP .NET Core. Its capabilities include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Executing processes and commands on the infected machine</li>
<li>Manipulating the file system</li>
<li>Capturing the screen</li>
<li>Stealing credentials from browsers</li>
<li>Stealing credentials for an aerospace-industry job application platform, which could contain sensitive aerospace data</li>
</ul>
<p>FalseFont was observed in the wild, packed in a single native executable that is 182 MB in size. In addition to the malware itself, this executable contains various .NET components and libraries essential for the malware to operate. FalseFont also uses <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/signalr/introduction?view=aspnetcore-8.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ASP.NET Core SignalR</a>, which is an open-source library for running web applications, for communication with its command and control server (C2).</p>
<h3><a id="post-133071-_diivtxjw6m3v"></a>Targeting Aerospace and Defense Job Applicants</h3>
<p>The FalseFont backdoor is a highly targeted backdoor, and so far it has been reported to target job applicants in the aerospace and defense industries. FalseFont targets these applicants by impersonating a graphical user interface (GUI) for submitting a job application to a U.S.-based aerospace company. Figure 1 shows the main window of the application.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133074" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133074" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133074" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-286597-133071-1.png" alt="Image 1 is a login panel. Log into your account. Display name or email. Password. Remember me. Forgot password? Login. Or don't have an account? Login as guest. Your privacy matters. Image of an aerial view of a beach and ocean." width="900" height="599" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133074" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Login panel displayed after running the FalseFont executable on a Windows machine.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Threat actors often imitate legitimate products for malicious purposes. This does not imply a flaw or malicious quality to the legitimate product being abused.</p>
<p>While the GUI is active for user interaction, in the background, the second and main component of the malware is running. As it runs, it is establishing persistence and registering itself to its C2 server.</p>
<p>FalseFont’s execution is detected and prevented by Cortex XDR, as shown in Figures 2 and 3.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133110" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133110" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133110" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/image5.jpg" alt="Image 2 is a screenshot of Cortex XDR when executable behavior has been detected. The screenshot includes tags, the module, the severity, the description, and the action to take." width="600" height="300" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133110" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. The alert reveals the FalseFont executable attempting malicious behavior while Cortex XDR is in detect mode.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_133108" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133108" style="width: 600px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133108" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/image14.jpg" alt="Image 3 is a screenshot of Cortex XDR. The screenshot includes the tags, the module, the severity, the action, and the description." width="600" height="258" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133108" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Cortex XDR shows it blocked the execution of the FalseFont malware.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-133071-_sohi76muwlzm"></a><strong>FalseFont Technical Analysis</strong></h2>
<h3><a id="post-133071-_iijo2stzkf4a"></a>The GUI Component</h3>
<p>The FalseFont executable presents a login interface impersonating an aerospace company, as previously shown in Figure 1. If a victim enters a username and password, the malware sends this data in JSON format through an HTTP POST request to the threat actor's C2 server on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64.52.80[.]30</span> over TCP port 8080. URLs for the regular login and guest login are different, as shown below in Figures 4 and 5.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133080" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133080" style="width: 419px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133080" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-296467-133071-4.jpeg" alt="Image 4 is a screenshot of the HTTP POST request code. Some of the information has been redacted. " width="419" height="132" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133080" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. HTTP POST request generated when logging in as a guest from the FalseFont GUI.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_133082" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133082" style="width: 416px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133082" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-299243-133071-5.jpeg" alt="Image 5 as a screenshot of the HTTP POST request generated when using a verified login from false font. Some of the information has been redacted." width="416" height="128" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133082" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. HTTP POST request generated when using the regular login from the FalseFont GUI.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The FalseFont GUI has a checkbox labeled <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Remember Me</span> immediately below the login fields. If a victim checks this box, the username and password are saved to a file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">data.txt</span> under <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%localappdata%</span>. On future launches of the application, if the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">data.txt</span> file already exists, the threat will send login data to the C2 server automatically. If this file exists or the C2 server responds successfully, the threat collapses the login view and displays a resume collection page shown in Figure 6.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133084" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133084" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133084" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-301861-133071-6.png" alt="Image 6 a screenshot of resume collection page. It includes fields for personal information, employment, eligibility, and education. Some of the information has been redacted." width="900" height="601" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133084" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. FalseFont GUI displays a resume collection page.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Once a victim fills these fields out, FalseFont converts their contents into serialized JSON and sends it as a GET request to the C2 server’s IP address. If the C2 server responds, the GUI shows the text “<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Your information has been registered, our colleagues will contact you</span>.” and the resume data is saved to a file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">data2.txt</span> under <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%localappdata%</span>.</p>
<h3><a id="post-133071-_swgl5rz0dpld"></a>The Backdoor Component</h3>
<h4><a id="post-133071-_fgglck9ln29a"></a>Initialization</h4>
<p>During initialization, FalseFont establishes a first handshake with its C2 domain. The malware collects and sends the machine hostname, the login username and the operating system details. Figure 7 below shows the packet sent to the C2, including the attackers’ credentials hard-coded in FalseFont’s code.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133086" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133086" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133086" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-305071-133071-7.jpeg" alt="Image 7 as a screenshot of the HTTP POST request for the initial command and control handshake. It is in the form of a TCP stream." width="900" height="103" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133086" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. TCP stream of an HTTP POST request for the initial C2 handshake.</figcaption></figure>
<p>FalseFont can use the following command-line arguments, which are referred to in the program’s code as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AppReset</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AppUpdate</span>:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SsQP's*(58vaP!tF4 (AppReset)</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SQP's*(58vaP!tF4 (AppUpdate)</span></li>
</ul>
<p>These arguments let the malware know if the C2 server has sent a request for a reset or an update. Next, FalseFont attempts to create a mutex with the value <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">864H!NKLNB*x_H?5</span>. In case the mutex already exists, and none of the arguments mentioned above were received, the malware will terminate.</p>
<h4><a id="post-133071-_jtgz3kpq89yx"></a>Persistence</h4>
<p>FalseFont drops three copies of itself into the infected machine, using the following distinct paths:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%username%\AppData\Roaming\host.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%username%\AppData\Local\broker.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%username%\AppData\Local\Microsoft\System.exe</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 8 below shows the file writing operations as logged by Cortex XDR.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133088" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133088" style="width: 504px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133088" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-307647-133071-8.png" alt="Image 8 is a screenshot of action types and file pass that alert on FalseFont in Cortex XDR. There are three file writes in total. Some of the information has been redacted." width="504" height="152" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133088" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Information from the Cortex XDR alert on FalseFont making three copies of itself.</figcaption></figure>
<p>FalseFont will then establish persistence via the registry <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CurrentVersion\Run</span> key for all three copies by creating a new value, as shown in Figure 9.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133090" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133090" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133090" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-310249-133071-9.png" alt="Image 9 is a screenshot of registry updates in Cortex XDR. Some of the information has been redacted. The information includes the type, the key name, and the registry data." width="900" height="142" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133090" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Example of registry updates to keep FalseFont persistent on an infected Windows host.</figcaption></figure>
<p>After startup only the backdoor component will run, excluding the malware’s GUI. In addition, if there are already values present in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Run</span> key, it will edit the first of the existing keys so it will also execute the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">host.exe</span> copy of FalseFont. Whichever starts up first will create a mutex that will terminate the other two instances.</p>
<p>The persistence mechanism of FalseFont following the infected machine’s reboot is detected by Cortex XDR as shown in Figure 10.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133092" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133092" style="width: 400px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133092" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-313272-133071-10.png" alt="Image 10 is a screenshot of a tree diagram in Cortex XDR. Some of the information has been redacted. The tree has three branches which all alert on different .EXE files." width="400" height="606" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133092" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Cortex XDR alert showing persistent copies of FalseFont starting after a reboot.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-133071-_nyd2c7rcya6"></a>Encoding and Encryption Scheme</h4>
<p>FalseFont stores a hard-coded configuration as part of its code, which attempts to conceal some of its strings to hinder analysis of its functionality. The malware’s strings are encoded in Base64, and encrypted using a hard-coded AES key.</p>
<p>The authors did not do a great job concealing the threat’s functionality, as they labeled most of the methods with names similar to the strings they decrypt and decode. Figure 11 below shows an example, with the string being decoded and decrypted into <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">OS error while executing</span>:</p>
<figure id="attachment_133094" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133094" style="width: 500px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133094" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-315981-133071-11.png" alt="Image 11 is a screenshot of a snippet of code. The embedded string is both encrypted and encoded." width="500" height="83" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133094" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. An example from FalseFont code where an embedded string is encrypted and encoded.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-133071-_am5zfqtrs8m9"></a>Core Functionality</h4>
<p>FalseFont has an array of commands it can receive from the C2. These commands enable the attackers to perform the following activities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Executing commands and processes</li>
<li>Downloading and uploading files</li>
<li>Receiving information about the file system</li>
<li>Updating the malware</li>
<li>Stealing credentials</li>
<li>Capturing the victim’s screen</li>
</ul>
<p>FalseFont can receive commands from the C2 in two different ways:</p>
<ol>
<li>Sending a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GET</span> request with the URI <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/api/Core/Command/Init</span> to a specific <a href="https://blog.hubspot.com/website/api-endpoint#:~:text=An%20API%20endpoint%20is%20a,a%20resource%20on%20the%20server." target="_blank" rel="noopener">API endpoint</a> on the C2 every 0-5 minutes</li>
<li>Using a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SignalR#:~:text=SignalR%20is%20a%20free%20and,David%20Fowler%20and%20Damian%20Edwards" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SignalR</a> client</li>
</ol>
<p>These two methods enable the attackers to interact with FalseFont in two different ways. By using method number one, the attackers are able to communicate with the backdoor via a predefined list of commands that it will execute every few minutes. With the second method that uses SignalR, the attackers are able to send each command to the backdoor in real time, without having to wait for the backdoor to send a request first.</p>
<p>As shown in Figure 12, the communication with the C2 is AES encrypted with a hard-coded key and then Base64 encoded. The key together with the URL list used for C2 communications can be found in the Indicators <a href="#post-133071-_re5lfhtpycch">of Compromise</a> section.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133096" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133096" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133096" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-318522-133071-12.png" alt="Image 12 is a screenshot of a few lines of code. FalseFont is using AES to encrypt communication." width="700" height="94" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133096" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Code snippet of FalseFont shows the use of AES for encrypted communication.</figcaption></figure>
<h5><a id="post-133071-_8xlul3hpqt3r"></a>Supported Commands</h5>
<p>Table 1 below contains FalseFonts’s supported commands from querying the “<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/Core/Command/Init</span>” URI.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 26.9934%;"><b>Command Type</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 72.3422%;"><b>Functionality</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Exec</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Executes a specified process with provided command-line arguments. Sets </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ProcessStartInfo.UseShellExecute</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to false, indicating the process should be run directly from the executable. Returns either standard output or custom strings indicating success or failure.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ExecUseShell</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Executes a specified process with provided command-line arguments. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Sets </span></span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ProcessStartInfo.UseShellExecute</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to true, indicating the operating system shell should be used to spawn the process. Returns either standard output or custom strings indicating success or failure.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ExecAndKeepAlive</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">This command doesn't appear to be fully implemented. It returns a command result of </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Not work</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and a status of </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CMD</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If the threat receives the parameter </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">pass</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> from the C2, it steals passwords from the Chrome, Brave and Edge User Data folders using code borrowed from a </span><a href="https://github.com/simpleperson123/ChromeDecryptor" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><span style="font-weight: 400;">GitHub project</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Otherwise, it executes </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd.exe</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> with provided command-line arguments and returns console output or custom error messages. </span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">PowerShell</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Executes </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">powershell.exe</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> using the provided arguments. Returns output or custom error messages.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">KillByName</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Attempts to kill a process by name using </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Process.Kill</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Returns successfully terminated process IDs.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">KillById</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Attempts to kill processes by ID using </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Process.Kill</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Returns successfully terminated process IDs.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Download</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Downloads and decompresses a file hosted on the C2 server. Returns a string indicating success or failure.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Upload</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Uploads either a single file or directory, or a list of files and directories to the C2 server. Data is exfiltrated in Base64 encoded and encrypted chunks of a size specified by the C2.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Delete</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Deletes a specified file or directory. Returns a custom string indicating success or failure.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetDirectories</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Generates a recursive list of files and directories in a specified path, and returns a string that is delimited using the “<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">|</span>” character.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ChangeTime</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Updates the </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">_timeInterval</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> property controlling the SignalR client’s automatic reconnect timer.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SendAllDirectory</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Enumerates all logical drives and returns a list of all subdirectories and files to the C2.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">UpadateApplication</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Downloads, extracts and installs a new version of FalseFont. Executes using the </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AppUpdate</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> variable and terminates the current process.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Restart</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The threat launches the first identified copy of itself found in a registry </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Run</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> key, passing in the </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">AppReset</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> variable as an argument. Terminates the current process.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetProcess</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Returns a list of all running processes to the C2, using </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetProcess</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SendAllDirectoryWithStartPath</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Returns a recursive list of subdirectories and files under a specified path, or multiple paths delimited by the “<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">*</span>” character.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 26.9934%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">default</span></td>
<td style="width: 72.3422%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Returns “</span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Command not register</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">.”</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #999999;"><em><span style="font-size: 8pt;">Table 1. Commands supported by the C2’s <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">init</span> URI.</span> </em></span></p>
<h5><a id="post-133071-_dv4le7nxkpoh"></a>SignalR Client</h5>
<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SignalR#:~:text=SignalR%20is%20a%20free%20and,David%20Fowler%20and%20Damian%20Edwards" target="_blank" rel="noopener">SignalR</a> is an ASP.NET library, commonly used for chat applications, enabling servers to push content to clients in real time.</p>
<p>As opposed to the method mentioned in the section above that queries a specific <a href="https://blog.hubspot.com/website/api-endpoint#:~:text=An%20API%20endpoint%20is%20a,a%20resource%20on%20the%20server." target="_blank" rel="noopener">API endpoint</a> every few minutes, the attackers are able to send a command to the backdoor in real time using SignalR.</p>
<p>FalseFont uses SignalR’s default JSON-based text protocol, which means the attacker's server sends messages in a JSON format that is handled and parsed by different handlers registered by the client (FalseFont). Messages from a SignalR server contain a name and additional parameters.</p>
<p>As shown in Figure 13, FalseFont registers five handlers using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.aspnetcore.signalr.client.hubconnectionextensions.on?view=aspnetcore-8.0#microsoft-aspnetcore-signalr-client-hubconnectionextensions-on(microsoft-aspnetcore-signalr-client-hubconnection-system-string-system-func((system-threading-tasks-task)))" target="_blank" rel="noopener">HubConnectionExtensions.On</a></span> method. Once registered, the SignalR client will wait for messages from the server. When it receives a message, it will check if the message name matches one of five possible values. If the name matches, the corresponding method is executed and the message parameter field is passed in as an argument.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133098" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133098" style="width: 860px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133098" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-321373-133071-13.png" alt="Image 13 is a screenshot of many lines of code. It is a list of register handlers for SignalR messages." width="860" height="191" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133098" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. FalseFont’s registers handlers for SignalR messages.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Table 2 below shows an overview of the handlers registered for FalseFont’s SignalR client.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 18.3554%;"><b>Method</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center; width: 80.9801%;"><b>Functionality</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 18.3554%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Command</span></td>
<td style="width: 80.9801%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Executes a command from the same list that is supported by querying </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/Core/Command/Init</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> URI.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 18.3554%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetDir</span></td>
<td style="width: 80.9801%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Collects a list of files and directories at a specified path. Sends a POST request with the data to the </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/api/LiveDirectory/Send/Dir</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> endpoint.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 18.3554%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetHard</span></td>
<td style="width: 80.9801%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Enumerates hard drives, including name, type and size. Sends a POST request with the data to the </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/api/LiveDirectory/Send/Hard</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> API endpoint.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 18.3554%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetScreen</span></td>
<td style="width: 80.9801%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Creates a new thread that captures screenshots at a specified interval over a specified duration of time. The screenshots are saved as JPEGs, converted to Base64 and sent to the </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/api/LiveDirectory/Send/Screen</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> endpoint.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 18.3554%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">StopSendScreen</span></td>
<td style="width: 80.9801%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Disables the screen capture method.</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 8pt; color: #999999;"><em>Table 2. Commands supported by the SignalR client.</em></span></p>
<h5><a id="post-133071-_8i586y4eam8i"></a>Credential Theft</h5>
<p>Examining FalseFont’s credential theft feature, we observed that if FalseFont receives the command <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CMD</span> with the parameter <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pass</span> from the C2, it will attempt to steal credentials from popular web browsers.</p>
<p>Additionally, FalseFont will attempt to steal credentials by querying the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Loginvault.db</span> database, as shown in Figure 14.</p>
<figure id="attachment_133100" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-133100" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-133100" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/word-image-323983-133071-14.png" alt="Image 14 is a screenshot of many lines of code. FalseFont attempts to query a .DB file." width="700" height="162" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-133100" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. FalseFont code showing attempts to query the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Loginvault.db</span> file.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-133071-_uomlt8uabyk4"></a><strong>Conclusion</strong></h2>
<p>This article provides a technical analysis of FalseFont, a new backdoor developed by the suspected Iranian-affiliated threat actor known as Curious Serpens. We reviewed how FalseFont’s operators target the aerospace and defense industries by attempting to mimic legitimate human resources software specific to these industries. This disguised executable ultimately causes the installation of the backdoor under the guise of a job recruitment process.</p>
<p>We then dived into FalseFont’s core architecture, functionality and its elaborate interface to receive commands from the threat actors in real time. We also analyzed the framework that the threat actors chose for C2 communication, which included the implementation of a dual communication mechanism.</p>
<p>Lastly, we also showed how the Cortex XDR platform can detect and prevent the malware’s different infection components.</p>
<p>We urge security professionals and defenders to carefully examine this report and leverage the information presented to improve existing practices in detection, prevention and hunting, ultimately fortifying their overall security stance.</p>
<h2><a id="post-133071-_tdjc227tnpj1"></a><strong>Protections and Mitigations</strong></h2>
<p>For Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this threat.</p>
<p>The Cortex XDR platform can detect and prevent the execution flow described in the screenshots included in the previous sections.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsiam" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> detect user and credential-based threats by analyzing user activity from multiple data sources, including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Endpoints</li>
<li>Network firewalls</li>
<li>Active Directory</li>
<li>Identity and access management solutions</li>
<li>Cloud workloads</li>
</ul>
<p>Cortex XDR and XSIAM build behavioral profiles of user activity over time with machine learning. By comparing new activity to past activity, peer activity and the expected behavior of the entity, Cortex XDR and XSIAM detect anomalous activity indicative of credential-based attacks.</p>
<p>They also offer the following protections related to the attacks discussed in this post:</p>
<ul>
<li>Preventing the execution of known malicious malware</li>
<li>Helping prevent the execution of unknown malware using <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/subscriptions/threat-prevention" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Behavioral Threat Protection and</a> machine learning based on the Local Analysis module</li>
</ul>
<p>Cortex XDR Pro and XSIAM <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/analytics-alerts-by-required-data-source" target="_blank" rel="noopener">detect post-exploit activity</a>, including credential-based attacks, with behavioral analytics.</p>
<p>Prisma Cloud Defender agents with <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XSIAM/Cortex-XSIAM-Administrator-Guide/Pairing-Prisma-Cloud-Compute-with-Cortex-XSIAM-Beta" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> and <a href="https://docs.prismacloud.io/en/compute-edition/32/admin-guide/configure/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WildFire</a> integration can detect and prevent malicious execution of the FalseFont binaries within Windows based VM, container and serverless cloud infrastructure.</p>
<p>The <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> with the <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-threat-prevention/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Threat Prevention</a> security subscription can help block the malware C2 traffic via the following Threat Prevention signature: <a href="https://threatvault.paloaltonetworks.com/?query=86805" target="_blank" rel="noopener">86805</a></p>
<p>The <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/datasheets/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of this new FalseFont backdoor. Multiple products in the Palo Alto Networks portfolio leverage Advanced WildFire to provide coverage against FalseFont and other threats.</p>
<p><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DNS Security</a> categorize known C2 domains and IPs as malicious.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-133071-_re5lfhtpycch"></a><strong>Indicators of Compromise</strong></h2>
<p>FalseFont packed executable SHA256 hash:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">364275326bbfc4a3b89233dabdaf3230a3d149ab774678342a40644ad9f8d614</span></li>
</ul>
<p>FalseFont unpacked executable SHA256 hash:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">4145e792c9e9f3c4e80ca0e290bd7568ebcef678affd68d9b505f02c6acaab12</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Mutex:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">864H!NKLNB*x_H?5</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Persistence paths:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%username%\AppData\Roaming\host.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%username%\AppData\Local\broker.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%username%\AppData\Local\Microsoft\System.exe</span></li>
</ul>
<p>C2 Domain:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Digitalcodecrafters[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<p>C2 IP:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">64.52.80[.]30</span></li>
</ul>
<p>C2 username:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MX2</span></li>
</ul>
<p>C2 password:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NooVtlXgx2T3IyN4I0Xf</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Base 64-encoded hard-coded AES IV:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">viOIZ9cX59qDDjMHYsz1Yw==</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Base 64-encoded hard-coded AES key:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3EzuNZ0RN3h3oV7rzILktSHSaHk+5rtcWOr0mlA1CUA=</span></li>
</ul>
<p>C2 URI Scheme:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Login/</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">LoginAsGuest/</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">realtime/</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">api/</span>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/Token</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/AgentRequestTime/Agent</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/Core/Command/Add/Result</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/Core/Command/Add/Schedule</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/Core/Command/Init</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/Core/Command/Last</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/Core/Command/Restart</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/FileStorage</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/FileStorage/Agent/Init/Upload</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/FileStorage/Agent/Upload</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/FileStorage/Agent/Download</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/LiveDirectory/Send/Dir</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/LiveDirectory/Send/Hard</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/LiveDirectory/Send/Screen</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 21 June, 2024 at 10:34 AM PDT</span>-->

                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Pictorial representation of SnipBot.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="curious-serpens-falsefont-backdoor:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/snipbot-romcom-malware-variant/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="curious-serpens-falsefont-backdoor:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/backdoor/" title="backdoor" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="curious-serpens-falsefont-backdoor:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:backdoor">Backdoor</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/romcom/" title="RomCom" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="curious-serpens-falsefont-backdoor:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:RomCom">RomCom</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/snipbot-romcom-malware-variant/" title="Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="curious-serpens-falsefont-backdoor:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/08_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A pictorial representation of a red team tool like Splinter.                             </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="curious-serpens-falsefont-backdoor:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/analysis-pentest-tool-splinter/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="curious-serpens-falsefont-backdoor:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool">

            <figure> 
              <button class="close__modal" id="closeModal"> 
              <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/close-modal.svg" alt="Close button"></button>
              <img class="be__enlarged-image" id="enlargedImage" src="" alt="Enlarged Image">
              <figcaption> </figcaption>
            </figure>
          </div>
        </div>

      </div>
    </section>
  </main>
<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			              	 <source media="(max-width:400px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			               	 <source media="(max-width:949px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

        <div class="footer-menu-nav__wrapper">
                      <h3 class="footer-menu-nav__title">Company</h3>
                                <div class="nav-column__wrapper">
          <div class="nav-column">
            													<nav>
					<ul class="footer-menu-nav__list"> 
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item "> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/about-us"   role="link" title="About Us" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Company:About Us">About Us</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item "> 
							<a href="https://jobs.paloaltonetworks.com/en/"   role="link" title="Careers" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Company:About Us:Careers">Careers</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item "> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/company/contact-sales"   role="link" title="Contact Us" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Company:About Us:Careers:Contact Us">Contact Us</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item ">

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</body>
</html>
